19009188.review:
탐욕으로 똘똘 뭉친 모험가 무리를 응징하자!!

여러 던전에 적당한 지점에 트랩을 설치하여 적들로부터 던전을 방어해내는 게임. 오크 머스트 다이를 떠올릴 분들이 많을텐데(실제로 오크 머스트 다이에서 많은 영감을 받았다고 한다.) 일단 3D와 2D라는 그래픽상의 차이점이 있고, 직접 캐릭터를 조종해 적들을 대처하는 오크 머스트 다이와는 다르게 이 쪽은 오로지 트랩만 설치하여 적들을 무찔러야 한다는 플레이상의 차이점도 존재한다.

게임은 무난하게 재미있다. 각 트랩들의 균형이 나쁘지 않고 각 던전의 지형도 천차만별이니 각 던전마다 어떤 트랙을 어떤 식으로 활용할지 적절히 궁리하게 된다. 던전 클리어를 통해 얻은 젬을 바탕으로 각 트랩들을 업그레이드 시켜줄 수 있으며, 대체로 업그레이드 값은 톡톡히 해주는 편이다.

적들 역시 농부부터 전사, 기사, 도둑, 중장기병 등 여러 클래스가 다양하게 등장하며, 각 클래스마다 특성이 서로 달라 적당히 짜증도 나면서 게임 하는 맛도 난다. 각 던전마다 후반 웨이브에 접어들면 어마어마한 물량이 쏟아진다. 정말 세상엔 탐욕에 찌는 놈들이 많구나 싶으면서도 비좁은 곳에서 낑겨가며 던전을 침투해오는 것을 보면 어딘가 왠지 짠한 구석도 있다. 어쨌든 이런 점 때문에 후반보단 중반이 더 어렵게 느껴지는 게임이다. 디펜스 게임이 대체로 그렇긴 하다만.

또한 같은 던전이라도 더 어렵게 즐기고 경험치 더 챙기라고 각종 룬을 설정한 플레이와 무한모드인 엔들리스 모드도 존재한다. 게임 플레이에 여러 제약을 거는 룬들은 설정하고 클리어하면 그만큼 경험치를 더 많이 받게 된다. 4룬 이상 클리어를 통해 해금하는 엔들리스 모드 역시 룬을 활용할 수 있으며, 말 그대로 적들이 무한정 쏟아져나오기 때문에 트랩 배치만 잘 하면 경험치를 엄청 챙길 수 있다.

얼리 억세스 기간동안 후반부 던전들이 차근차근히 만들어진 구조다 보니 후반 던전들은 난이도가 좀 있다. 특히 마지막 보스전은 왠 공돌이 마왕 포스를 풍기는 드워프 할배가 고철더미를 타고 나와주셔서 더욱 고전하게 된다. 본인처럼 룬 모드나 엔들리스 모드를 플레이하지 않았더라면 브리즈룬을 활용하지 않고서는 조금 고생할 여지도 있다. 게임 중간중간 엔들리스 모드를 해금하고 즐기는 것이 여러모로 편할 것이다.

마침 디펜스 게임이 땡기던 타이밍에 정식 출시가 되어 상당히 재미있게 즐겼던 게임. 난이도가 약간 어려운 것을 감안한다면, 누군가 디펜스 게임을 추천해달라고 할 때 주저없이 추천해줄 수 있는 게임이다.

18972346.review:
A novel and surprisingly engrossing and addictive tower defense game--albeit, more accurately, dungeon defense.  Pesky heroes are assailing your various lairs en masse and it's down to you to devise elaborate combinations of booby traps and minions to keep them at bay.  Unlike most tower defense games where you're given a bevy of said towers to line some paths and periodically make some mazes, Dungeon Warfare's arsenal plays much more heavily into utilizing the surroundings and managing the different sorts of heroic intruders battering at your dungeon doors.

One of the most ready examples of this are the pits and chasms that you'll find in many of the locales; there are a number of physics and movement related traps that can push, catapult or pull intruders off ledges and send them tumbling into the abyss (the harpoon trap being particularly brutal and fun--firing a big tethered javelin into enemies and 'reeling them in'.)  

Different enemies have different properties, so a heavily armored knight is a bit harder to push around than their lighter fare.  Horsemen try to rush through your arsenal to batter down doors and bee-line for your inner sanctum, dwarves seek out your barricades to sap and destroy, adventurers try to duke it out with your minions and are generally nimble, etc.  Similarly, stages can include tracks with mine carts circulating them to plow enemies around in dangerous intersections, spiked walls ready for you to shove lines of troops against them, etc.  You'll also find giant boulders you can set tumbling to crush everyone in its path.

There are quite a few different traps and setups available at your disposal which can compliment one another fairly well.  I'm pretty fond of a lair that brings about a little necromancer who will go about raising slain enemies as a tiny army of skeletons.  Many of the traps bring Orcs Must Die to mind--but they're solid to take inspiration from (such as the springboards that launch enemies into pits, for instance.)  

Accompanying the traps are a bevy of cooldown-based powers you can utilize ranging from giant bear traps to bombs to eggs which hatch minions when enemies draw near or power-ups for your traps.  There is also an excellent 'trap mastery' system wherein you can invest gems to unlocking upgrades for your traps, reducing cooldowns / costs, making them do more damage, etc. (gems being earned by completing stages well and leveling up.)  You can also put gems into basic upgrades such as being able to sustain more enemies in your sanctum before losing, or starting the stages with more gold to work with--and leveling up also gives you more gold to start with as well.

Additionally, there are 'runes' which can be activated for stages to make them more challenging (faster enemies, fewer resources, limited load-out of traps, etc.) in exchange for more experience bonuses.  Completing a stage with four runes active unlocks the ability to play that stage in 'endless mode' for additional challenge.  Between the runes, large variety of traps and tools, I feel like there's plenty of mileage to be had--and that's before taking into consideration that the game includes a pretty easy to use map editor and Steam Workshop support.  Cool!

It's hard to fully do the full aesthetic experience of Dungeon Warfare justice in text and I feel like the screenshots don't necessarily do the game justice--but when you've got an elaborate gauntlet of death traps going full-force and a hoard of invaders trying to barge their way through it, it really gets quite rad.  It may seem a bit low-fi at first glance, but when grinders and darts and spring-loaded spikes are firing away while lightning arcs are chaining between knights and necromancers and demons are keeping footmen mired in boiling oil, it's all to fun effect.

If you're the sort that typically gives tower defense style games a pass, I'd urge a bit of a longer look at this one--I was very surprised by how deep it got its hooks in me; it is definitely the sort of game that if it clicks with you, you'll want to keep pushing on for 'just one more stage.'

Edit: Since release, Dungeon Warfare continues to receive excellent developer support by way of additional polish, making it all the more an excellent little game to revisit in your library!

If you are a fan of tower defense games you will probably like this. In fact, it might be one of my favorite TD games. At the very least I find myself continiously coming back to it in the same way I did the original defense grid. Maybe its just the early access nature of that. We will will see what happens now that version 1.0 is out.

If you are a fan of Orcs Must Die, then you will probably like this.

In fact, think of a 2D version of Orcs Must Die without the action components.

The over-game involves you leveling up traps and spells. In levels you then use these traps and spells to kill heros and what nots. You can chain your traps together to improve their effects. Have a hall of flame thrower traps. At the end of it, have a trap that pops up out of the floor to keep them stuck in the hall. Finally, after than have something that will fling them back into the hallif they get past it.

Ultimately though, if you are at all a fan of this genera, check it out. It's cheap and it's good.

18947946.review: One of a kind dungeon "tower defense" game. You're able to challenge yourself by setting limits for yourself and buffing the enemies (for better XP returns).  There's an underlying physics engine as well that enriches the entire experience as you watch traps spring into action. smacking your foes against walls, other traps, or even down into the pits. Nicely done pixel graphics. Even the sound design adds to the entire experience as you hear heroes and peasants alike fall into their deaths. Very fun game 10/10

18937683.review: Straight up fun with just the right amount of challenge. If it feels too easy, you have the ability to up the ante via runes before a stage to really test your designs  and  earn extra rewards. Brutal and satisfying traps make for some full-on meatgrinder stages. There is enough variety here to allow for a number of approaches to each level. 18929692.review:
This is one of the best, if not the best, pure tower defense games in a very long time.  

Depth:

There are numerous enemies with lots of different abilities, defenses, speed, etc.

20 towers, each customizable by placing points into them.  Most of them have 3 upgrades in game, a few only have 2.  

I counted 47 levels, but the map is kinda a mess so I could have easily missed one or two.


Challenge:

You can adapt any of the levels  to be as easy or difficult as you'd like.  Need to just beat a level to get the rewards (new tower or gems) but having problems?  Tone it down a bit with the "Breeze" rune.  

Looking for a challenge?  Load up to 10 different runes increasinng the difficulty greatly, but also the reward!  

Looking to go nuts?  Turn on the "Endless" rune and get ready for an increasingly difficult grind.


Replayabilty:

With all of the customization available, you can replay this game until your mouse breaks, buy a new mouse, then keep playing some more.  There is no end to the fun.


I highly recommend this game.

18928550.review:
Great tower defence game but could perhaps do with a few tweaks.

For instance having to replay a level because I didn't know it would throw a wave of 20 suicide bomber dwarves at me at the end that would shred my barricades instantly is slightly tedious. Being able to view all the wave lists before you start rather than just see the first six would be a good change.

A lot of the levels are clearly designed for you to use barricades to create a long and winding path of death to make the enemy march through. Or they have mine cart tracks to direct them onto. However due to the dwarves blowing up barricades it's often better just not to bother even trying to direct them. On endless mode it quickly becomes pointless having more than one or two barricades meaning that a lot of space on the level is unused. A lot of time is just spent with the repair tool hovering over what few barricades you do have and that gets a little tedious too.

I kind of think that the fully upgraded turret wielding version should be indestructible as it would give you a lot more options and makes levels more fun. Also it is kind of odd that you can build floor traps on top of this barricade which do nothing, except the lightning turret with AOE. It would be good if it could also use the AOE affects from some of the other traps, like poison, fire or bleed.

Once I had worked that much out and defeated the suicide bombers I got up past a million points on endless on one level only for my portal to be swamped by riderless horses that just charged through everything with dead riders but without a scratch on them. The giant stone golems and the heavily armoured knights fell before they'd even reached my main line of defence but the horses? Despite repeatedly running into walls and bouncing around all over the place whilst on fire and frozen with three harpoons in their backs and non stop lightning bolts frying them they still made it through. So yeah I think they might be a little bit over the top in their current state. Their speed and fact that they don't stop to fight liches or demons makes them powerful enough without also have more health than Jesus... and like Jesus you have to kill them twice.

Also when you do reach that stage in the game where the entire screen is filled with enemies you can't really see to build or upgrade anything. A build mode toggle option to hide all enemies whilst you place a turret would be nice. As would the ability to see the number of kills per turret or damage dealt.

18922231.review:
[i]Note[/i]: I have only experienced 4 hours of this game at the time I write this. I have yet to play through everything or even get the chance to use every tower. If my views change as I play more, I'll update this review.

[b]In Brief[/b]

If you like Tower Defense games, you will like this one. It doesn't do anything to revolutionize the genre, but throws in some cool towers/traps that add a nice twist, such as being able to push and pull mobs into pits. The pixel style is simple but both looks good and has good animations. The style most likely contributes to the games excellent performance, even when there are a lot of moving and effects on screen. The addition of a map editor is excellent, as most of my time so far has actually been making and playing my own levels. You can also share these levels to the Workshop as well as download and play the creations of other people, giving the game great replayability.

[b]Technical Stuff[/b]

Like I said, the game performs great. I had no issues with anything slowing down, glitching graphically, etc. I was also pleased to see the game ran perfectly despite my two monitor set up. It naturally assumed a Borderless Window sort of mode at 1920x1080 without any adjustments necessary. It's easy to click out to other windows if need be (which with games like this, I'm usually multitasking) and there were no issues using ALT+TAB to get in/out of the game.

[b]Minor Complaints[/b]

I think it would be nice to be able to zoom out a bit more than you are, but I don't know if that's technically possible with how the game is made. You do get some fairly large levels to play sometimes, and scrolling around and keeping track of things sort of artificially (perhaps intentionally?) makes the game harder.

Upgrading traps sometimes has the button appear underneath something else, such as a little dropdown at the top of the screen that shows you stats/info about the turret itself. You can still click the button easily enough, but it's just a nuisance that you can't really see what you're doing.

18912630.review:
Dungeon Warfare ist ein gutes klassisches TD mit einer kleinen Prise Hektik.
Man levelt ähnlich wie in GemCraft, bei der Wiederholung einer Mission bekommt man nur die XP, die über dem letzten Ergebnis liegt.
Mit Runen kann man sich eine Mission leichter oder schwerer machen und beeinflusst damit auch den XP-Multiplikator. Die Schwierigkeit schwankt stark von Map zu Map. 

[u]Grafik[/u]
Die Grafik ist pixelig, aber Grafik spielt für mich in TD-Spielen nur eine untergeordnete Rolle. Man kann die Auflösung frei wählen und auch im Fenstermodus spielen. Im Shop bekommt man einen guten Eindruck der Grafik.

[u]Türme und Fallen[/u]
Es gibt verschiedene Türme und Fallen, die durch erfolgreiche Missionen freigeschaltet werden. 
Türme können nur auf bestehenden Strukturen gebaut werden. Mit dem Level steigt auch die Anzahl der Türme, die mit in die Schlacht genommen werden können.
Die Pfade der Gegner können nur mit Barrikaden beeinflusst werden, diese liegen aber im mittleren Kostenbereich eines Turms und können von den Dwarfe Bomber beschädigt und zerstört werden. Übersieht man dies oder hat kein Gold für ein Upgrade oder Neubau, so ist die Mission so gut wie verloren (das ist die kleine Prise Hektik).
Während einer Pause kann man nichts machen und es gibt auch keine Speicher – oder Rückspulfunktion.

[u]Maps[/u]
Die Maps sind schön abwechslungsreich und man sollte die Besonderheiten der jeweiligen Maps beachten.
Es gibt schwarze Bereiche auf Maps in denen Gegner in den Tod fallen können, das ist ganz nützlich und man kann mit manchen Türmen oder Fallen nachhelfen. Genauso wenig freut es die Gegner, wenn sie in Wände mit scharfen Spitzen gedrückt werden. Es gibt auf einigen Maps sogar Züge, die Gegner umnieten oder wegstossen.

[u]Fazit[/u]
Gutes Spiel mit einfacher Grafik. Die Maps sind schön abwechslungsreich, aber die Schwierigkeit schwankt stark. Die im Angebot bezahlten 5.99€ gehen in Ordnung.

Mehr Empfehlungen zu Tower Defense Spielen:
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/8896126-Gametests-and-Videos

18911848.review:
敵が硬すぎるタワーディフェンスにうんざりしてはいませんか？ウェーブが進むにつれて敵のHPが指数関数的に上昇していき、最終的には絶対に倒せないボスに突破されてゲームオーバーになってしまうものを…

Dungeon Warfareではそんなことはありません。このゲームでは敵を固くする代わりに数で補っています。HP100の敵を10人だす代わりに、HP10の敵を100人出してくるのです。
すると何が起こるかというと…圧倒的な爽快感です。「爽快感」という言葉はちゃちな和ゲーでよく使われる言葉なのであまり使いたくないのですが、通常の10倍以上いる敵を剣山トラップで皆殺しにし、生き延びたタフなやつを押し出しトラップで奈落の底に突き落とし、それでもまだ生きていた運の良い奴を銛タワーで4方向から突き刺してバラバラにしていれば、例えこの言葉に嫌悪感を感じていても爽快感を感じるはずです。

ゲームバランスも初心者から上級者まで問題なく遊べるようになっています。ステージを開始する前に難易度を調節するルーンをつけるかどうかというダイアログが出てきます。ルーンには例えば敵のHPを20%増やす、ライフを1にするといった効果があるのですが、これをつけることにより難易度を好きに調節することが出来ます。ルーンを付ければクリア後に獲得出来る経験値が増えるので、自分の腕に合わせて賢く選びましょう。
また、このゲームは経験値によってタワーを強化することができるので、信じられないレベルのゲームオンチ、例えばクリボーを倒すのに横から触るのか上から触るのか分からない、もしくはヘッドショットをするのに頭を撃てばいいのかそれともつま先を狙えばいいのか不安な人でも、簡単なステージを繰り返しクリアすることによるレベル上げで最終的にはどんなステージもある程度簡単にクリアできるようになります。

エレメンタルTDからタワーディフェンスというジャンルを、デスクトップTDから迷宮づくり系タワーディフェンスという機能を、Kingdom Rushから兵隊という一時的な壁要素などなど…過去の名作タワーディフェンスのいいところだけを集めて磨いたようなゲームです。タワーディフェンスを好きな気持ちが0.02%でもあるのであれば、買って損はないでしょう。

18905554.review:
So, die erste Stunde Spielzeit ist vorbei und es wird Zeit für meine Meinung zu diesen kleinen, aber doch recht feinen Spiel.

Im Grunde genommen, ist dieses ein klassisches Tower Defense Spiel, welches nur das Setting ein wenig anders angelegt hat. Man ist der Besitzer einen Dungeons und Horden von Helden wollen einem das Herz des Dungeons zerstören.
Um die Helden daran zu hindern, kann man seinen Dungeon mit Fallen spicken.

Dort aufsteigenden Schwierigkeitsgrad und freischaltbaren neuen Fallen, hat man von Anfang an eine Lernkurve und fühlt sich eigentlich nie überfordert. Mit ein wenig Planung, schafft man die ersten Level recht leicht, ohne auch nur einen einzigen Gegner bis zu seinem Herz vordringen zu lassen.

Zusätzlich bietet das Spiel noch einen Leveleditor, welcher leider noch ein paar Bugs beinhaltet (Vertikale Türen verschwinden einfach beim Laden des Levels). Die Level lassen sich dann per Mausklick über den Workshop mit anderen Spielern teilen.

Das Spiel kommt mir persönlich nie langweilig vor und genieße aktuell noch jede Minute, die ich mit der Fallenplanung verbringe.

Um aus dem TD Einerlei herauszustechen, würde ich mir allerdings noch "Monster" wünschen, welche man ebenfalls in den Dungeon einbürgern kann. So als Dungeon Master fühlt man sich doch ein klein wenig einsam.

18878642.review:
Pixelated Tower Defense done very well!

If you like TD games, this one is worth the price of admission.  Charming pixel graphics lend well to the ultraviolence of dart, spike, and push traps, along with all the other fun tricks you'd expect.  The inclusion of a 'rune' system allows you to increase the difficulty on a given level, letting you enjoy it with a fair bit of replayability.  The music is a touch on the flat side, but the sound effects are spot on.  It's quite satisfying to hear a peasant fall to his death after your pusher trap shoves him into a pit.

Looking forwards to spending more time on this one, glad I bought it.

18878485.review:
Objectively the best TD on the market, and I've played nearly all of them. I found it challenging and intriguing, with loads of ways to complete levels, tons of strategies to employ, and the easiest level editor to use that I've ever seen.

The game takes tower defense to a new level, because not only do you have to kill enemies by shooting them or destroying them, you have a second method after playing the game for an hour or two, where you can shove enemies off ledges and insta-kill them, spring them, etc. It opens up whole new ways of destroying your foes.

If I had to classify this game with anything else, I'd put it on par with Orcs Must Die. Easily an 11/10 tower defense for me. And it has steam workshop, play it now! I bought it at full price, and if you see it on sale it's DEFINITELY worth the purchase!

17908455.review:
[h1]A fast-paced pixel-graphic slaughterfest[/h1]
[b]In a sea of copy-cat Tower Defense games, this game stands out[/b]

Dungeon Warfare is a mix of pathing and maze-based TD, giving you a little freedom to redirect enemies be blocking their path into your traps. The levels are all unique and challenging in their own way, and often require a little outside the box thinking to beat them. The difficulty level is adjustable per-level in this unique mechanism called "runes". Basically, you make the level harder on yourself and you get extra XP because of it.

I recommend running through all the levels with the newbie rune enabled (the top-left one) to unlock all the towers, then run back through all the levels increasing the amount of difficulty runes you enable.

Don't forget you can reset the towers you've upgraded and choose which towers to upgrade per-level.

[b]10/10 would play again and again, buy a sequel, buy a DLC.[/b]

16470032.review:
[h1]Shortest review: Orcs must die in 2D[/h1]

You like Tower-Defense? And you liked "Orcs must die!"? Then you'll love "Dungeon Warfare".
It's basically OMD without Orcs but with the usual fantasy-dudes.

Sometimes very challenging at first, at least if you want to "3-Star" every map from the start, which
gets slightly easier the more traps you unlock and the more gems you've earned. Sometimes
you'll just lack the more fitting trap for some maps. 

And even if you've 8-runed (each rune adds another difficulty like faster/harder/tougher mobs etc) all maps with 3 stars, you're not done. There's a very nice and
easy editor to make your own maps. In not 1 hour i've put together a very nice map with lots
of rounds that was actually fun to play. You can also publish your map right from the game.

But...early access?
This is by far the most complete, balanced and bugfree Alpha i've played in a while. I have
not much doubt the dev will deliver a fully polished product.
But even if he'd stop right now, i would not feel scammed, as it was a lot of fun for not much bucks :-)

[u]The good:[/u]
[list]
[*] Free placement of traps, no stupid fixed points (which are usually favoured by the lazy devs because it's easier to balance)
[*] Thanks to barricades: Mazing!
[*] Nice soundtrack (so far) and fitting SFX. Kicking mobs into a pit is very satisfying, even after 100 of them :-)
[*] Many more or less different enemies, each with its own strength and weakness
[*] All the usual OMD-traps and some more, all upgradeable
[*] ONE godly power you'll choose before a map. Like traps, spawns or a general recharge-reduction...
[*] Zoom-out-function for the quick overview
[*] You'll earn gems for which you can make traps better/cheaper/faster. Like the skulls in OMD
[*] You're leveling. Each levelup yields some gems and more importantly it raises starting gold for each map!
[*] Good balancing, considering it's still alpha, has leveling and upgradeable traps! No easy job to balance this. You'll need an asian for that ,-)
[*] A nice, friendly and dedicated dev who even publicly posts his email.
[*] A "re-setup" button after the first retry of a map. Never setup your traps manually all over again just because you've failed :)
[*] Even though it's 2D you'll never loose the overview. Even when it gets hectic. 
[*] 3-Star-System (none reached portal etc.) and on top of that: 8 runes you can activate that makes maps harder. Restrict traps, make mobs tougher/faster/more aggressive, increases cooldown etc.
[*] Easy to use editor included. Make your own maps!
[/list]

[u]The bad:[/u]
[*] The sounds can become a bit annoying after some hundred dead troops :-)
[*] AI seems even dumber than the orcs. If, e.g., mobs have the choice of 3 roads to take, they always choose the shortest way. Which means they choose the heavily trapped way instead of those free roads.
[*] Totally no story at all (yet). I personally don't care, but some may very well care.
[/list]

[u]The ugly:[/u]
[*] Nothing!
[/list]

Recommended? YES! Definately a pearl that needs more attention!

15655141.review:
[h1][b]■EarlyAccess（以下EA）について[/b][/h1]
ストアリリースの3月時点で約2ヶ月程度でリリース予定となっており、じき正式リリースされる（はず）。様々な理由からEAに悪い印象を抱く人もいるだろうがDungeon Warfareには一切心配は無用である。何故なら本作は既にリリース可能なクオリティに達している。理由はEAリリース前から[url=http://www.kongregate.com/]kongregate[/url]で数ヶ月のテストを既に実施済みらしくバランス等の調整も上手く出来ており、4月下旬のプレイ時ではほぼフルゲームと変わらない内容を楽しめた。EAながらレビュー評価も上々。5/3時点で全レビュー28件中オススメが100％。GL上がり、Bundle歴も有、定価も1180円のゲームでこれは珍しいのでは無いだろうか。ストア上のEA説明には正式リリース時は実装される内容のボリューム多寡によって少し上がるかもしれないとの事。面白いゲームではあるが余程のTDファンでも無い限り定価で買うゲームでも無いがセール時や再Bundleされる事があればぜひチェックして欲しい作品。

[h1] [b] ■ゲームについて[/b][/h1]
2D見下ろしタイプの一般的なTD。ダンジョンの支配者となり侵攻してくる強欲な冒険者を殺すという設定。ステージは32面。20トラップ。敵が17種。難易度や様々な設定を変更できるMODが9種。プレイヤーが悪玉側で騎士や魔術師、僧侶や盗賊、商人等を殺していく設定も面白くもあるが本作の一番の面白味は罠で冒険者を仕留める爽快感だろう。英語レビュー数件ではOMDに例えられていたが確かにOMDに出てくるトラップに近似するものは多い。地面から槍が出てきて串刺しにする、タールで足を遅くする、スプリングや押し出しで敵を奈落へ落とす、壁から矢や槍で敵を射抜く、火炙りにする、グラインダーで敵を磨り潰す等などOMD経験者には想像に易い罠が沢山出てくる。ザクッと突き刺す、ブオォーと火で炙る、チュイーンとミンチにする、奈落に落として「アーッ」と響く断末魔を聞く等々、これが中々に楽しいのである。ちなみに全ステージクリア済みでプレイ時間は約15時間程度。今後はレベルエディターを実装しWorkshop対応予定との事でこちらにも期待したい。

[h1][b]■マイナス評価[/b][/h1]
トラップの設置費用がやや高い。罠を設置しまくり虐殺しまくるといった事が出来ない点が不満。罠での敵処理が楽しいゲームだけにこの点は残念。あとはマップがやや狭い点が少し不満に感じた程度。楽しめたゲームだがカジュアルなTDと言ってしまえばそれに尽きる。

[h1][b]■その他[/b][/h1]
バンドルを買いそびれたけど興味があるといった人は、まず以下を試してみるのも良いと思う。STEAM版に比べて1/2以下のトラップやステージ数、難易度MODしかないらしいが雰囲気やプレイフィールを掴むには十分かと思われる。

[h1]This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer.[/h1]

Dungeon Warfare is an amazing take on the tower defence genre. This type of game is probably my favourite genre bar RPG. The game does a very good job of introducing different traps each level, allowing you to get to grips with each of them so you know how best to use them. 

The art style is pleasant, I have no issues with a tower defence type game being in the pixel graphics. One of the cool features in Dungeon Warfare is before each level, you are able to select a rune (more than one if you want), each run has a specific debuf which affects you the whole level, but you'll also gain extra experience, there is also one rune which debuffs the enemy and buffs you, but you do get less experience, which is to be expected. 

I liked how you could spend gems which you gain for completing a level and going up a level on upgrading your traps. Personally I found the dart gun to be the most effective throughout the whole game. I just set up barricades to create "corridors of death" with multiple dart traps on each end, it seemed to be a winning formula for me. 

I have put about eight hours into Dungeon Warfare and have only just finished the campaign. I highly recommend this game, even if you aren't normally a fan of the genre.

15273004.review:
Dungeon Warfare is an addictive pixel art tower defense strategy game that sees you playing as a dungeon lord, laying all manner of traps and obstacles to defend your dungeon from pesky looters and adventurers.

As with most Tower Defense games, each level consists of waves of enemies charging through your dungeon, as you lay out traps to maximise the damage they do to stop them reaching your gold.  Starting off with a couple of basic traps, you soon unlock more and more deadly ones, such as huge rolling boulders or portals to summon your own troops.  You also gain XP which can be used to purchase permanent upgrades for each trap, reducing cooldowns and increasing damage.

It’s a fun game, and the difficulty level soon ramps up to offer a tough challenge that will have you fine tuning your dungeon layouts to get them just right – nobody steals your gold and gets away with it!

15244566.review:
Fantastic little tower defense game, one of the best among the top-down point-and-click ones. I'd rate it right after Defense Grid. It's the traps that fling enemies around and the environmental hazards that make it special, they are very fun to put into place and the effects can be downright hilarious. Orcs Must Die had those first, but if you want the same kind of action without the running around (which for me detracts from the strategy, rather than adds to it), this is the game for you.

The progression system is pleasant and very flexible: new traps are unlocked by completing specific levels, and all levels you finish give you upgrade points to improve turrets. The twist is that those are not just passive upgrades: you unlock lvl 2 of your pusher traps, but you still have to upgrade them in the course of a level using gold from killing invaders. You can redistribute your upgrade points between levels to specialize differently. You can also increase the difficulty of a level by choosing challenges that grant you more XP if you win.

Level design is good with a lot of variety; some involve a little bit of mazing using barricades. Traps can mostly be placed in pre-existing walls — a few can be placed on the floor — so you don't get the type of freeform design present in Defense Grid where you can build elaborate mazes and your turret themselves act as walls. Perhaps some levels could allow you to place walls, or even some track sections! (Yes there are deadly minecarts running around.) 

Overall the gameplay is solid and interesting, so much so that while playing it I find myself wishing to see it used as the base of a larger game of dungeon management. It's a well-crafted and super fun tower defense. Buy it now.

Dungeon Warfare is a game of tower defense with an out-of-the-box twist. Unlike with typical TD games, Dungeon Warfare lets you interact with the hordes of monsters. This adds a whole new twist to the game's gameplay.

It is no longer about bombarding your monsters with as much firepower as you can, but instead this game relies on strategies that allow you to kill multiple monsters with one stone.

Include the fact that you are able to interact with an active environment with holes, boulders, and mining carts that you can use to your advantage or disadvantage.

I've played numerous tower defense games, but Dungeon Warfare is in a league of its own, and has set the bar to new heights.

~~ Eagerly waiting for the next update(s) ~~

15160489.review:
Rarely have I been this excited about a Greenlight game getting onto Steam. I love, love, LOVE Dungeon Warfare. As a Tower Defense game, it does everything right: It's easy to learn and challenging to beat. It features new variations on a classic theme.  It offers on-rails or creative placement, whichever you prefer. Most important: It's just plain fun.

There are nice touches here that weren't in the Greenlight version. First, there is a feature between levels that allows you to actually increase the difficulty of your game in up to 8 different ways (for example, by reducing your lives to only one, reducing the number of traps you can use, or increasing enemies' strength, speed, or health). Why would you want to do this? Because each additional, potentially crippling selection will increase your xp multiplier! In short, as long as you have the cajones, you can gain some serious xp and, thus, level in fairly short order.  Conversely, you can also make things a bit easier for yourself, at the cost of 40% off any experience you might earn for that board.

That said, the game still offers balance, and I've never felt overpowered, even as a level seven player on board three. Each level up grants you an ever-increasing number of gems that can be spent to power-up your traps. As new areas are conquered, branching paths open up, offering more variety. Beating each area offers its own rewards, ranging from gems to opening up new trap slots.

Speaking of variety, there are a number of interesting traps on offer, from push walls to floor spikes; from barricades to melee fighting, demon-spawning portals; from darts to spin blades. The fun comes in trying different combinations, along with using the environment. Watching a well-placed push wall shove an enemy into a bottomless pit, for example, is quite satisfying (and the humorous sound effects really make the moment).

There are a couple of things that could be improved upon (navigation of the playfield could be better implemented), but the simple truth is this: As I write this, Dungeon Warfare is only on its ninth alpha release, and it's [i]already[/i] in better shape than most full releases. I can't wait to see what's coming.

For fans of the genre, this is well worth the full price of $11.99.

Dungeon Warfare is an amazing Tower Defense game.

I have been playing Dungeon Warfare from the moment it became available. I have spoken with Groquest, one of the game's developers, for over a month about the game. Thanks to him, I was able to make videos on Youtube (linked at the bottom) about the game, and they show just how far Dungeon Warfare has come. Initially the game was pretty bare bones, but it was still immensly fun.

There are many different traps in the game that are unlocked by completing levels. The traps range from dart traps that shoot adventurers, to sticky traps that slow them down, to harpoon traps that fire into adventurers and pulls them into pits. There's something extremely satisfying about hearing an adventurer fall into an endless pit after being harpooned in the chest.

I highly suggest this game to anyone looking for a strategy game, or a tower defense game. I have always been a huge fan of TD's, including Bloons, Orcs must Die, GemCraft, and many more. I often find myself playing a level or two every night just before bed. I definitely recommend this game. If you're looking for more of a review, here's a link to my YouTube playlist for the game.

15014249.review:
Before to start the review, I’d like to say that I’m really big TD lover from the age of Warcraft3.

As you know, most of the types of TDs that you can find in the market today, has been defined at that time.

Personally, I suppose there are two categories as a big picture, and those are like below;

1.	One – way TD
You can only install the tower along the path which is fixed, the only thing that you can arrange is ‘when’ you install ‘which’ tower.
This type of TD is really easy to build for the developer, because of easiness of leveling the difficulty.
It is really predictable, and there are no many options for the players to get the goal.

2.	Maze type TD
You make your own path with the barricades or obstacles, the only thing which is fixed is entrance and the exit of enemy.
This type can be provide wide range freedom to the player, because this TD is all about “how”.
But it’s really hard to get a proper leveling.
Because depends on the players’ skill, it can be too easy or too hard. And also, it’s really difficult to design vary maps.
Usually in this case, the differences between maps are only types of enemy or types of tower that you can build.
This limit is also connected to the difficulty of the leveling itself.

Actually, I prefer the Maze type TD, but it’s really hard to find in the market recently. Because of the limit that I’ve mentioned above, it’s almost not proper as the product to sell. 

Because its natural defect on the volume of the game.

 If you want to sell a TD to the gamer, you have to put “reasonable number of maps” in the game. But not like one way TD, maze TD’s maps can be really similar each other in the different meaning. Because for one way TD, developer can set only one path in one stage, but in the Maze TD there are so many possible ways to play in one stage. So to say numbers of map set itself, one way TD has really big advantage.


Sorry for so long prologue, but I just like to explain why I like this Dungeon Warfare this much.


This TD is ultimate-proper hybrid which is mix of those two types,


DW, it’s not fully maze type, but it is providing maximum level of the freedom for the player with the aspect below.

1.	There is no tower type limit for stages, except very beginning of the game.

2.	Always there are bypass to make a way.
 There are many kinds of obstacles in the map tile set that player can use. it can help player to make a maze or can be irritating.

3.	But as a design of map, each map has its own character because of fascinating unique features that you would never find in another TD.
(You never miss the mine cart)

Not only the map design, but also there are many attractive in many aspects.


1.	You can set the difficulty very specifically. Normally TD has very simple difficulty level, but in DW, you can set many kind of abilities of enemy.
Especially what I love is the “weight of enemy”. This thing can affect hugely to the game.
This is a really good example that simple physics how could help make game fun. Bigger unit is slower, heavier ,and harder to throw into the air.
It’s really natural, but I couldn’t stop laughing when I saw this.

2.	There are many kinds of towers that you can get.
I played only 14 hours, and I’m really bad at gaming unfortunately, even I love so much.
So I couldn’t go that far. But already I have 9 types of towers, and each of them are very fresh. Especially Harpoon, Push, and the spring.
I will not mention the specific function of those here. Because if you see the towers in the game that I’ve mentioned, you would know what I mean “fresh”.

3.	User-friendly UI.
Except mini-map, which I want to complain about, There is all the needed user interface. Very comfortable to play, and very noticing.

4.	Volume of game.
 I wonder why this game has the early-access tag. This game seems already finished to build, well defined, and has enough volume to play not like other early-access.
I heard there are 30 maps, and with the difficulty set up that I’ve mentioned, I think it can guarantee more than 30 hours of playing time.


But also there are a few things must be improved further.


1.	Music
I know this is indie game, and there are no many developers to serve on this minor issue, but still it will be really nice if this game has more music.
Although the main-theme is well made for an old gamer, but only one theme for almost 30 stages is still not satisfying.
       I’m playing with my own music, so actually this is not a big issue, but.. 

2.	MINI MAP!!!!!
Please put a mini-map in the UI. It’s really hard to notice if only one enemy sneak out from my maze in the big map. This defect can be more noticeable when you play multi-entry stages.
Especially when you play one-life mode, this can be really critical. 


So I reviewed this game with my humble word, but I’m pretty sure that I couldn’t express enough the wonderfulness of this game.

Go and get it, and it will give you the maximum fun for 10 bucks.

14961125.review:
Dungeon Warfare is the game where you kill or you die.

To more accurately describe the game, Dungeon Warfare is a tower-defense game focusing on installing traps in pre-defined dungeons in order to kill waves of enemies. The game starts you out with access to only two basic traps: The floor-mounted spike trap, which periodically juts up deadly spikes to damage the enemies above it, and the the wall-mounted dart trap, a device that continuously fires darts at whatever direction it is pointed at. As you progress through more of the levels, more traps types become available. Want to push enemies into a bottomless abyss? The pusher trap's got you covered. Want to burn them? The flamer will take care of that. Want to summon demons to fight for you? You can do that too. Each trap type is unique and varied, with over 13 different types as of this writing and more on the way. The fact that you can only take a limited number of trap types with you into a level means that you will need to plan out your defenses ahead of time. Often I've found myself having to decide just how I was going to deal with that massive wave of peasants in wave 5, for example.

Speaking of enemies, the enemies that you are fighting are more "good" than most things usually found in dungeons. In Dungeon Warfare YOU are the big bad evil guy, defending your portal from the legions of good. From the humble peasant, slow and weak but deadly in large numbers; the rough and tough warriors, able to take a beating; the theives, quick enough to bypass most of your traps; the mighty knights, that push your damage skills to the test; to the haughty nobles, that have more gold than they know what to do with; with over 12 different enemy types, every enemy in Dungeon Warfare is unique and presents a different challenge to the player.

The game deals with progression well, allowing the player to learn how to deal with each new enemy type over the course of levels. The game utilizes an experience system to reward the player with bonus starting gold for all levels, as well as "gems". In this game, gems are the currency used to upgrade the trap mastery of each trap, with increasing cost per level. For example, raising your spike trap mastery to level 5 takes 10 gems, as 1 (Level 2) + 2 (Level 3) + 3 (Level 4) + 4 (Level 5). The effects of trap mastery are twofold. Immediately, each increase in level affects the stats of a particular aspect of each trap type: For spike traps, it is a percentage increase in damage, for dart traps, the cooldown time between shots is decreased by a percentage, etc. There is no need it be worried about spending your gems on the wrong upgrades; at any time between levels the player can reset their gems at no cost, allowing them to mix up their play style for the next level. The second effect is that for every 5 levels in a trap mastery the player gains, the player unlocks a new tier of upgrades for that trap. These are straight upgrades that the player can spend gold on during a level to upgrade a single trap, and the upgrades often cost less than it does to place a new trap, although sometimes more can be better; again, depends on the playing field of the level.

On the topic of levels, for that matter, the game boasts a count of 29 unique maps as of this writing, with more levels being added each week. Also, while not currently implemented, the game will include a level editor that will allow the player to make their own custom levels and share them through steam workshop. Level layout will determine your strategy, forcing you to adapt. Some levels have natural defenses in them, such as bottomless abysses, thin corridors, and minecarts running through the map; figuring out how to best use what you're given is up to you.

In Dungeon Warfare, your experience total is the sum of all of your best scores across all levels, meaning that it pays to go back and revisit a level to boost your score. What seperates this from most games is the Modifier system that the game uses. In each level, you can choose from nine different modifiers that make the game more (or less!) challenging. Each modifier changes different aspects of the game: The "Nil" modifier decreases the bounty you get from killing enemies by 10%, forcing you to be frugal; the "Anchor" modifier increases enemy health by 5%, and enemy weight by 100%, making shoving them into the abyss much harder; the "Breeze" modifier is for those that are having difficulty, increasing the spawn times between waves, lowering enemy speed and health, but also cutting your score by 40%. All the modifiers affect your final score with multipliers, and up to 8 modifiers can be stacked (with the exception of the breeze modifier) to provide a massive challenge that, should you emerge victorious, gives you a outrageous multipler of x5.23 for your final score for the level. Be warned, this challenge is not for the weak; you will need all the skills you can muster for this monster difficulty.

All in all, Dungeon Warfare is a promising Early Access game. With more content being continuously added, massive replayability value, and a creator that is vocal and very visible to the public, this is one game you don't want to miss. Now get out there, and wage some DUNGEON WARFARE!

Then you'll suddenly slam into two levels (one is called "Echoing screams" or something) that are basically impossible, even after 50-plus tries. 40548806.review:
[h1]●トラップで敵を蹴散らす、見下ろし2Dタワーディフェンス[/h1]

ゴール地点へ向かう敵の進路に罠を張り巡らせ、
全ウェーブを凌ぐ物量系のタワーディフェンス。
とにかく敵の数が凄まじく、雪崩の如く流れ込む事も。
敵を倒してゴールドを稼ぎ、罠の強化や追加設置をする事が重要だ。

- - - - - - - - - -

ステージをクリアしていく事で新たな罠がアンロックされていく。
地形に設置する罠と、場所を指定して発動させる罠の2通りがあり、
他にも大岩やトロッコ、扉などのギミックも存在する。

ステージをクリアする事で経験値(スコアと同義)を得られ、
一定以上溜まるとレベルアップし、ボーナスが貰える。
この時貰えるジェムが罠のレベルを上げるための通貨となる。
ちなみに経験値はステージ毎に記録されており、
前回クリア時を上回った分だけが新たな経験値として計上される。

難易度が物足りない場合は、ルーンと呼ばれる要素で難易度を上げられる。
ルーンを追加すると、その種類に応じた強化が敵に施される。
その分獲得経験値も増えていくので、経験値稼ぎには必須だ。
(例外的に、難易度を下げる物とエンドレスモードに変更する物がある)

ステージ毎の罠の構成を考えたり、罠を強化する成長要素が楽しいし、
大量の雑魚をなぎ倒していくのはなかなか爽快感がある。
ボリュームも申し分無く、Steamワークショップにも対応している。
タワーディフェンスに興味があるならオススメだ。

40181949.review:
爽快感のあふれる見下ろし型の2Dタワーディフェンスです。
これでもかと湧いてくる敵の軍勢をトラップでミンチにしてあげましょう！
※うれしい日本語対応

チュートリアル含め基本45ステージ+隠し2ステージの計47ステージ。
トラップは、設置型のものとプレイヤーが任意のタイミングで使用するものの2種類。
前者は20種、後者は8種となっており、ゲーム進行に応じてアンロック。
これらはステージクリア及びレベルアップで強化していくことが可能。
自分の体力1、敵攻撃力増加、といった制約(ルーン)を任意に追加することで、レベルアップが早まります。

迷路は半自由に構成でき、バリケードにより敵の進行経路を変化させることができます。
その気になれば複雑な迷路も作成できるかもしれません。
しかし、基本的にはマップの構造に準じたプレイングとなるでしょう。

私は、基本45ステージクリア時点で27時間。実績は25/35でした。
隠しステージや限定的な条件にかかわる実績も含まれるため、実績コンプには40時間以上かかりそうな様子。

本作にはマップエディタが備わっており、Steamワークショップにはユーザ作成のマップが140以上あります。
また、1度クリアしたステージではエンドレスモードで遊ぶことも可能。
これらまで遊びつくせば相当なボリュームになるでしょう。
量産型の退屈なTDに飽きた人にはおススメです。

This game is SO good. This TD is on par with Gemcraft Chasing Shadows as being one of the most customizable tower defenses ever. You can adjust the difficulty as you please, while being rewarded more for choosing harder "runes". These runes do things like increase enemy health or make you earn less gold from kills. My favorite thing about this game is the way it treats itself like an arcade game. You get bonus points for scoring long "killstreaks" which is done by killing an enemy within a certain time after the previous kill.
Lastly, the towers are INCREDIBLY creative, there is no other TD I can think of with such a fun and interesting set of weapons.
If you just bought the game, keep in mind that the further you progress, the more variety you get in terms of gameplay, so dont be discouraged by the repetitive nature of the first few levels. Trust me, the longer you play, the more fun it gets.

39702465.review:
This game represents a quiet overhaul of the Tower Defense genre.

It's an overhaul managed not through gimmicks or character, but by careful thought, scrupulous attention to detail, and flawless level design. The careful balance between joyous physics-based carnage and the varied strategies you'll need to win at the highest level make this game near-perfect.

Even minor flaws with the TD genre have been removed here, and their absence balanced for. Ever get frustrated waiting for a gap in a creep wave so you could drop an essential barrier? Here, you just drop the barrier and watch the creeps explode. The catch is that barriers are expensive (more than some damaging traps), and you have limited room for placement.

Much like Defense Grid: The Awakening was the definitive Tower Defense game of the 2000s, this game is the definitive Tower Defense game of the 2010s...at least, until they release the sequel.
